title: CS1102 Linux Shell Lab
text:
VM-Access

Open your terminal/command prompt/powershell from your system (NOT from the VirtualBox)
For simpler setup do not enter any passphrase and skip all the prompts by pressing Enter
Type ssh-keygen in the terminal/command prompt/powershell and Enter. You should see output similar to the following:

<username>@my-laptop:~$ ssh-keygen
Generating public/private rsa key pair.
Enter file in which to save the key (/home/<username>/.ssh/id_rsa):
Created directory '/home/<username>/.ssh'.
Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase):
Enter same passphrase again:
Your identification has been saved in /home/<username>/.ssh/id_rsa
Your public key has been saved in /home/<username>/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
The key fingerprint is:
SHA256:MyMwAvTo90BeuaGhaS9aq3Lc2QivijK7oMkigMCm14Y <username>@my-laptop
The key's randomart image is:
+---[RSA 3072]----+
|o.               |
| .o   .          |
|...+o+           |
|oo=.+oo          |
|== B .. S        |
|= E =  . +       |
|o+.* =           |
|%o+.= .          |
|#Oo.             |
+----[SHA256]-----+

By default, if the file is not specified


Public key will be stored as ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub or C:\Users\<username>\.ssh\id_rsa.pub.
Private key will be stored as ~/.ssh/id_ed25519 or C:\Users\<username>\.ssh\id_rsa


To view the public key, use cat command to display the content of the public key which ends with .pub inside the ~/.ssh directory (by default) (For Windows follow the above directory structure)

cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub (or)
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub 

Copy and paste the content of the public key (NOT THE PRIVATE KEY) that ends with .pub into the “SSH Key” form field on the website (use your student email ID to log in).
After submitting the SSH key, you can log in to the VM using SSH from your system.


Ensure the directory ~/.ssh with file permission 700
Ensure the files ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub and ~/.ssh/id_rsa with file permission 600.


The following command used to connect remote machine via SSH using the default private key (~/.ssh/id_rsa or ~/.ssh/id_ed25519)

ssh <roll-number>@cs1102.study.iitm.ac.in

The below command used to connect remote machine via SSH using the custom private key path

ssh -i <path/to/private/key> <roll-number>@cs1102.study.iitm.ac.in

Once, you have logged in your command prompt will look like:


<roll-number>@cs1102:~$







Note



Read more about SSH by clicking here

title: Instructions for Online Lab
text: How to do lab questions in the VM?

title: Instructions for Online Lab
text:
Complete each question only after logging into the course VM and following the format below while taking screenshots:

If the question requires you to complete the task on your local PC, then follow the below format:


Execute the date command (e.g., Sat Jan 25 01:22:00 AM IST 2025).



Add a comment on the next line: # Roll_no  Name
(e.g., 25f1234567  YOUR NAME HERE)



If any questions require working with files, they can be found in either /opt/assets or /opt/cs1102-notes/lab_tasks







Important




The command prompt from the CS1102 course VM must be visible in the solution screenshot for every question
If there is no prompt, you will receive zero marks in that lab

title: Instructions for Online Lab
section: How to write a Lab Report in Google Doc?
text:
How to write a Lab Report in Google Doc?

In the Google Doc, create a new tab for each lab (Example: If you doing the Lab-1, create a tab named Lab-1)
Create outlines for each questions (Example: Create a outline named Question 1 if you are solving that question 1) in each tab, to navigate the questions easily. Check here to know about how to create a outlines in the document
Stick to the question sequence as given in the problem statement while answering the lab
Ensure that the screenshots are clear and that the text is readable. Screenshots containing very small or blurred images will be rejected
A lab report must include the questions along with their corresponding answer screenshots
Align your document well and maintain the consistent font size and font style throughout the document. Preferably,

Font size - 11 (normal text) and 14 (heading)
Font style - Open Sans (medium)

Check the lab document template here







Important




If your doc/report does not follow format above, it will not be evaluated









Tip




Feel free to use document comments to communicate with your lab TA.
Once you complete the lab work for a particular lab, tag your TA in your lab report and let him/her know.
Your TA’s will also give feedback on the questions using the comments in the google doc.

title: Instructions for Online Lab
text:
Action on Malpractices/Plagiarism
If you engage in malpractice or plagiarism, the following actions will be taken:

You will be required to repeat the entire lab in the next term.

A remark regarding malpractice will be added to your degree.

Malpractices include (but are not limited to):

Using other student’s answer screenshot
Using or sharing answers with another person.

title: History of the man Command
text:
The man (short for manual) command in Linux is primarily used to view the offline documentation for commands, system calls, library functions, and other parts of the Unix/Linux system. While it is a common misconception that man was initially created specifically for viewing header files, its origins are broader and tied to providing documentation for Unix systems.

Origins:

The man command was introduced in Unix Version 3 (1971) as a way to access documentation on Unix commands and features.
It was designed to provide structured, formatted manuals for users to learn about tools, utilities, and programming interfaces available on the system.

Header Files:

While man does include sections related to programming and development (such as system calls and library functions), these sections often reference or document concepts found in header files (like stdio.h, unistd.h, etc.).
The misconception may arise because programmers frequently use man to read documentation that involves header files.




Structure of man Pages
The man pages in Linux are divided into sections, with each section focusing on a specific category of information. These sections help users quickly locate the relevant documentation for commands, programming interfaces, or system tools.
Here’s a breakdown of the sections with examples:








Section
Content
Examples




1
User Commands: Commands available to all users, typically found in /bin and /usr/bin.
ls, grep, man (e.g., man ls or man 1 ls to view the manual for ls in section 1).


2
System Calls: Functions provided by the kernel. These are low-level operations.
open, read, write, fork, kill (e.g., man 2 fork for the fork system call).


3
Library Functions: Functions provided by standard C libraries, such as glibc.
printf, malloc, strcmp, fopen (e.g., man 3 printf for the printf library function).


4
Special Files: Documentation on device files in /dev or special kernel files.
/dev/null, /dev/random, /proc (e.g., man 4 null for the /dev/null device file).


5
File Formats: Describes the syntax and structure of configuration files.
/etc/passwd, /etc/fstab, /etc/hosts (e.g., man 5 passwd for the /etc/passwd file).


6
Games and Screensavers: Fun and miscellaneous programs available on the system.
tetris, fortune, xlock (e.g., man 6 tetris if a game is installed).


7
Miscellaneous: Topics that don’t fit into other sections, such as standards and conventions.
man-pages, locale, regex, signal (e.g., man 7 signal for signal handling in Linux).


8
System Administration Tools: Commands for managing the system, typically requiring root.
iptables, systemctl, mount, umount (e.g., man 8 iptables for firewall management).






Additional Examples

1 (User Commands): echo, cd, touch, chmod, ssh
2 (System Calls): execve, mmap, socket, exit
3 (Library Functions): memcpy, atoi, popen, pthread_create
4 (Special Files): /dev/sda, /dev/tty, /proc/cpuinfo, /sys
5 (File Formats): /etc/crontab, /etc/ssh/sshd_config, ~/.bashrc
6 (Games and Screensavers): nethack, adventure, xscreensaver
7 (Miscellaneous): ascii, timezone, ld.so, standards
8 (Admin Tools): fdisk, cron, reboot, sudo, service







Tip



Use the -a flag to view all matching sections for a term. For example:
man -a kill
This will show both the user command (section 1) and the system call (section 2) for kill.

title: Grading Document (Jan 2025)
text:
Introduction to the Linux Shell Lab
Corequisites: Introduction to the Linux Shell      Credits: 1
The Introduction to the Linux Shell Lab consists of two components:

title: Grading Document (Jan 2025)
text:
Online Lab (OL):
Online Lab assignments:
This lab will be conducted online during the course. The start dates for the labs are as follows:

Lab 1: Released on 01 February
Lab 2: Released on 15 February
Lab 3: Released on 01 March
Lab 4 and 5: Released on 15 March

Labs are typically expected to be completed within 4 days. Teaching Assistants (TAs) will be available to assist you during this period.

title: Grading Document (Jan 2025)
text:
In-campus Lab (IL):
In-campus Lab work: Students are required to visit IIT Madras for lab work.
Lab Dates:

Slot 1: May 30th to June 2nd 2025
Slot 2: June 6th to June 9th 2025

Eligibility to attend the in-person lab:

Average of all online lab scores >= 40/100.

Eligibility to obtain the final lab course grade:

Average of all lab scores >= 40/100.
Attend the in-person lab at IIT Madras

title: Grading Document (Jan 2025)
text:
Final Grading of Lab

Online Lab(OL): Average of all 5 lab scores
In-campus Lab(IL): 1 * Lab task and demonstration

Final course score (T) = \(0.5*(OL)+0.5*(IL)\)

title: How to solve the questions in the VM?
text:
Log in to the VM using ssh <roll-number>@cs1102.study.iitm.ac.in
To view all the available questions in the directory

ls /opt/cs1102


Create a directory in your home folder using mkdir cs1102 and navigate to the directory cd cs1102



Your command prompt should now look like this:


<roll-number>@cs1102:~/cs1102$


Solve each question by creating a directory named after the question(example practice_2.1)

mkdir practice_2.1
cd practice_2.1

After navigating to the practice_2.1 directory, type synchro show to view the question



Solve the question by either writing the script <script>.sh or by executing commands directly in the command line, as instructed in the question
Ensure that you have the necessary permissions to run the script. If not, change the script’s permissions using chmod 755 <script>.sh
Run synchro eval to submit the question. It will display the submission status and show how many test cases you have passed or failed
To view the public test cases and evaluation script for the question, navigate to ~/opt/cs1102/<question>/public







Important




synchro init - to iniatilize or bring all the neccessary files to solve the problem
synchro show - to view the question
synchro eval - to submit and evaluate the question

All these commands needs to be executed within the directory (~/cs1102/<question>)

synchro status - to view the number of questions you have solved

All the instructions are also available in the course VM itself. You can read them by batcat ~/README.md
crumbs: 5  How to solve the questions in the VM?

title: Troubleshooting the VM
text:
1. Permission Denied (Issue 1)
The error message Permission denied (publickey) indicates that the SSH server is not accepting your public key for authentication. Below are some common reasons for this error and the steps you can take to resolve it:
Solution: Reupload your ssh-key in the site

title: Troubleshooting the VM
text:
Incorrect or Missing Public Key on Server


The public key (id_rsa.pub or id_ed25519.pub) that you provided might not be correctly added to the ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file on the server or it might be missing altogether.



Incorrect Private Key or Key Pair


You may be using the wrong private key (id_rsa or id_ed25519) to connect to the server, or the key pair does not match.

ssh -i /path/to/your/id_rsa <RemoteUserName>@<hostname>

Make sure the private key file permissions are correctly set

chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_rsa

Wrong Username


Double-check the username (roll number) in your SSH command. Make sure you are using the correct format:

ssh <CorrectRemoteUserName>@<hostname>

Wrong Domain Name


The domain name you typed might be wrong. Double check the domain name in your SSH command.

title: Troubleshooting the VM
text:
2. Remote Host Identification Changed (Issue 2)

Go to cd ~/.ssh(for Linux or Mac) or cd .ssh (for Windows)
Remove the known host files with rm known_hosts and remove known_hosts.old if it exists using rm known_hosts.old
Then execute the following command ssh-keygen -R cs1102.study.iitm.ac.in
You can login now using ssh <roll-number>@cs1102.study.iitm.ac.in







Note



If all the above steps fails, then it is recommended that students generate a new key using the instructions provided in the course website where they initially entered the key to get ssh access.








Read more about troubleshooting the VM by clicking here
